According to the data, Junsuk and Junhyuck actively positioned themselves as cultural resources inside and outside the classroom by presenting different opinions and by challenging the dominant groups’ hidden power. Although they were able to enact their agency under the dominant power, the process was propelled and expanded when teachers’ support for their identity was provided. The boys more actively participated in learning activities when they were recognized by their teachers and peers. The results indicate that an “asset-based approach” (Borrero & Yeh, 2010, p. 580) that positions immigrant students as cultural assets is desirable to assist their success. As Moje and Luke (2009) claimed, students “come to imagine future positions and their future selves moving within and across those positions” (p. 430). It is about time that teachers focus on immigrant students’ difference as an asset and seek for the specific practices to help the students vision and position themselves as capable and confident.

For this asset-based approach, it is fundamental that teachers utilize “funds of knowledge” (González, Moll, & Amanti, 2005) that immigrant students bring to the classroom for all students’ learning. As their mother, I often heard from Junsuk and Junhyuck that they were surprised that many American peers do not seem to have sufficient knowledge of other countries and are even unaware of how little knowledge they have about global perspectives. Given that the United States is one of the most diverse countries with different ethnic groups in the world, this realization from the siblings is an interesting aspect for teachers and educators to consider. Teachers might think about utilizing cultural resources that the immigrant students bring to the classroom by viewing their cultural and linguistic differences as strengths and by allowing them to teach peers. When immigrant students are viewed as invaluable cultural resources and are allowed to bring their identity and culture into the classroom, all students might have opportunities to broaden their cultural understandings.

In this process of utilizing immigrant students’ cultural resources, recognizing the various layers of context, culture, language, positioning, and identity is a starting point to avoid preconceived ideas of immigrant students as one single group. As demonstrated by Junsuk and Junhyuck, who, even with the same environment and the same family support, developed their academic and social skills in different ways, each immigrant student works in her or his own way to define who she or he is and to become successful through dynamic positioning. Just as Junsuk and Junhyuck constructed and reconstructed their identities, immigrant youth have those abilities. The key point is that we researchers and educators recognize the importance of identity for the students’ success and support their sense of agency. Indeed, this study suggests that educators listen to individual students’ narratives, observe their positioning, and celebrate their unique abilities.

Finally, educators might consider the ways in which they work with immigrant parents to support immigrant students’ identity. There are no “silver bullet” skills and strategies. The basic premise is to understand the importance of identity for the immigrant students’ educational and social success as shown in this study. Through their children’s classroom activities and assignments, immigrant parents receive implicit and explicit messages from the teachers whether they respect their children’s identity. As Junsuk and Junhyuck did, immigrant students might share with their parents how their teachers approach them. As an immigrant parent myself, it was not difficult to sense what was happening in the classrooms. When the parents perceive that their children’s teachers value their primary culture, they might encourage their children to sustain their cultural identity at home and at school.

Based on my formal and informal observations, many immigrant parents seem to view assimilation to the mainstream culture as the best way for their children’s success in the United States. I often heard from Junsuk and Junhyuck that many of their immigrant peers were discouraged from exhibiting their ethnic identity due to the fear of rejection by peers and teachers. Some parents even encouraged their children to hide their identity by dying their hair to a lighter color or to inhibit their use of their native language. These immigrant parents’ perceptions might have developed from ungrounded or grounded reasons in the mainstream culture. Teachers’ implementation of cultural inclusivity in the classrooms is an important model to show the parents that the students’ cultural identities are appreciated and should be sustained for their success. Although the economic and social situations of the immigrant parents might be different, most parents care for their children and hope for their success (Sobel & Kugler, 2007). It is important for teachers to share their support for the immigrant students’ identity with their parents. They can work together as “partners” to enact the students’ agency by recognizing their unique talents and abilities. The teachers and parents bear the responsibility of supporting immigrant students to reconstruct the context in which they can find their educational and social spheres.
